FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
August 20, 2020

GPS School Year Off to a Smooth Start

Guthrie students went back to school this morning and the early reports were a very smooth start. Some finishing work is awaiting completion at the sites who received new entrances and contractors are continuing their work.

According to Dr. Mike Simpson, Superintendent of Schools, “I did my customary tour across the district and principals at all buildings reported a very smooth drop off process. We had two buses that were running late, but that is to be expected on the first day. Moving the Senior drive to a time after other sites have started has made the first day much more manageable across the district. Many procedures are changing as we adapt to school with COVID-19 protocols. We ask you to please be patient with the many changes which include mandatory masks for visitors.”

The hallways are quiet tonight. Tomorrow, we will open school for the first time since March 13th with a desire to stay open and serve our students. This will require some changes and we ask our community support those changes. Secondary schools will have routing plans and one-way stairways. Visitors to our buildings will be restricted much more than in the past and cannot enter the building without wearing a mask.

If you have questions, please call your child's school. Remember, we are in this together and doing the best we can to serve our students in an unprecedented time. Have patience and offer grace to our staff. They are on the front lines working daily to provide the best education possible for our community.

It is no secret that school will look different this year. Here is some of the signage being placed in our buildings to remind students and staff of the need to social distance when possible and continued diligence in hand washing.

There are changes to how students will navigate through the buildings at the secondary level during class change passing periods. Students at GUES will not change classes as the teachers will rotate classrooms. Routing plans for how students walk through the building have been developed for Junior High and High School students. Also, in many cases, lunch periods have been added to decrease the number of students in the lunchroom. All students will have seating charts for lunch, in the classroom and on buses.

Please prepare your students for these necessary changes as we stay safe.

AN IMPORTANT MESSAGE ABOUT FRESHMAN ORIENTATION AT GUTHRIE HIGH SCHOOL

Freshman Orientation is scheduled for August 18th, and 19th from 6:30 pm-7:15 pm in the high school cafeteria. In an effort to reduce the number of students present and to promote social distancing, the event will be held over the course of two evenings.

On Tuesday night, students with a last name beginning with the letters A-L will meet for orientation while on Wednesday night students with the last name beginning with the letters M-Z will gather.

We encourage participation as this is a great opportunity to familiarize oneself with the building, locate specific classrooms, learn traffic flow routes throughout the hallways, and to connect with an upperclassman serving as a student mentor.

Should you have further questions please feel free to reach out to our Link Crew Sponsor, Tiffany Dement, at tiffany.dement@guthrieps.net.

shared_text:
Mike Simpson
April 5 at 11:38 PM ·

Many people including myself have used unprecedented to describe the event we are currently enduring. As it turns out, it is not unprecedented. On October 9, 1918, Guthrie Public Schools closed and did not reopen until November 11, 1918. The board minutes simply call it influenza but it would become known as the Spanish Flu.

Another interesting tidbit about that closure is they grappled with the support staff pay as well. In Guthrie, janitors were not paid if they were not called for work during that period. At that time, there was no Child Nutrition Staff, definitely no Technology Staff and probably no Transportation Staff as well.

Here are the minutes from the Guthrie Board of Education Meeting for November 4, 1918.

ATTENTION TO ALL WHO VISIT OUR SCHOOL SITES

Last Friday, a new law went into effect which allows, in many cases, open or concealed carry of a firearm without a license. This law DID NOT change any statute as it applies to carrying a firearm on school property. Currently, only sworn peace officers are allowed to carry a firearm on school property. We ask that they have clear identification of their status as a peace officer as well. This includes all school property regardless of the function or sponsor.

The only exception allowed is a firearm may be carried inside a car (non-school owned vehicle) in the parking lot. The firearm must be out of sight at all times. If the vehicle is unattended, it must be locked.

Here are the before and after pictures of the GHS track. This facility is used by virtually every athlete at GPS. It also serves as a location for local first responders when they need to renew their certifications. In the evening, many community members can be seen working on their fitness as well.

The previous surface was installed in 1996. A track typically last for 10-12 years if properly maintained. This project was funded through the 2015 bond issue since the original projects came in below budget estimates. Additional funding came from interest earned from the bonds as well as building fund proceeds.

The track will open on July 8th after the surface has cured properly.

In addition to the normal maintenance that goes on each summer at GPS, we have several projects that are underway. Many of you have shown interest in the seating project in the GHS Gymnasium. Our custodial staff have been cleaning the seating areas since the old seats have been removed. It has taken a lot of effort to remove the many years of use! New seating is scheduled to be installed in mid-July. Currently, the track is being resurfaced and we expect that project to be completed very soon if we can finally get mother nature to cooperate.

These projects have been possible because the bond projects in 2015 bond came in under budget! We are also using revenue generated by interest earned from the bond proceeds as well as money from the building fund.

Guthrie Public Schools greatly appreciates the support of our community.
